explicit

Interface STPG

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Model, NondetModel
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    STPGAbstrSimple, STPGExplicit

    public interface STPG
extends NondetModel
    Interface for classes that provide (read) access to an explicit-state stochastic two-player game (STPG).

    These are turn-based STPGs, i.e. at most one player controls each state. Probabilistic states do not need to be stored explicitly; instead, like in an MDP, players have several 'choices', each of which is a probability distribution over successor states.

    For convenience/efficiency, STPGs can actually store two transitions/choices in two ways. The first is as described above: a state has a list of choices which are distributions over states. #getNumChoices(s) gives the number of choices, #getAction(s) gives an (optional) action label for each one and #getTransitionsIterator(s, i) provides an iterator over target-state/probability pairs. The second way is 'nested' choices: the choices in a state are instead transitions directly to states of the other player. Each of those states then has has several choices that are distributions over states, as above. The middle layer of states are not stored explicitly, however. If the ith choice of state s is nested in this way, then #isChoiceNested(s, i) is true and #getTransitionsIterator(s, i) returns null. Use #getNumNestedChoices(s, i), #getNestedAction(s, i) and #getNestedTransitionsIterator(s, i, j) to access the information.

      • prob0step

        void prob0step(java.util.BitSet subset,
               java.util.BitSet u,
               boolean forall1,
               boolean min2,
               java.util.BitSet result)
        Perform a single step of precomputation algorithm Prob0, i.e., for states i in subset, set bit i of result iff, for all/some player 1 choices, for all/some player 2 choices, there is a transition to a state in u. Quantification over player 1/2 choices is determined by forall1, forall2.
        Parameters:
        subset - Only compute for these states
        u - Set of states u
        forall1 - For-all or there-exists for player 1 (true=for-all, false=there-exists)
        forall2 - For-all or there-exists for player 2 (true=for-all, false=there-exists)
        result - Store results here

      • prob1step

        void prob1step(java.util.BitSet subset,
               java.util.BitSet u,
               java.util.BitSet v,
               boolean min1,
               boolean min2,
               java.util.BitSet result)
        Perform a single step of precomputation algorithm Prob1, i.e., for states i in subset, set bit i of result iff, for all/some player 1 choices, for all/some player 2 choices, there is a transition to a state in v and all transitions go to states in u. Quantification over player 1/2 choices is determined by forall1, forall2.
        Parameters:
        subset - Only compute for these states
        u - Set of states u
        v - Set of states v
        forall1 - For-all or there-exists for player 1 (true=for-all, false=there-exists)
        forall2 - For-all or there-exists for player 2 (true=for-all, false=there-exists)
        result - Store results here

      • mvMultMinMax

        void mvMultMinMax(double[] vect,
                  boolean min1,
                  boolean min2,
                  double[] result,
                  java.util.BitSet subset,
                  boolean complement,
                  int[] adv)
        Do a matrix-vector multiplication followed by two min/max ops, i.e. one step of value iteration, i.e. for all s: result[s] = min/max_{k1,k2} { sum_j P_{k1,k2}(s,j)*vect[j] }
        Parameters:
        vect - Vector to multiply by
        min1 - Min or max for player 1 (true=min, false=max)
        min2 - Min or max for player 2 (true=min, false=max)
        result - Vector to store result in
        subset - Only do multiplication for these rows (ignored if null)
        complement - If true, subset is taken to be its complement (ignored if subset is null)
        adv - Storage for adversary choice indices (ignored if null)

      • mvMultMinMaxSingle

        double mvMultMinMaxSingle(int s,
                          double[] vect,
                          boolean min1,
                          boolean min2)
        Do a single row of matrix-vector multiplication followed by min/max, i.e. return min/max_{k1,k2} { sum_j P_{k1,k2}(s,j)*vect[j] }
        Parameters:
        s - Row index
        vect - Vector to multiply by
        min1 - Min or max for player 1 (true=min, false=max)
        min2 - Min or max for player 2 (true=min, false=max)

      • mvMultMinMaxSingleChoices

        java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> mvMultMinMaxSingleChoices(int s,
                                                            double[] vect,
                                                            boolean min1,
                                                            boolean min2,
                                                            double val)
        Determine which choices result in min/max after a single row of matrix-vector multiplication.
        Parameters:
        s - Row index
        vect - Vector to multiply by
        min1 - Min or max for player 1 (true=min, false=max)
        min2 - Min or max for player 2 (true=min, false=max)
        val - Min or max value to match

      • mvMultGSMinMax

        double mvMultGSMinMax(double[] vect,
                      boolean min1,
                      boolean min2,
                      java.util.BitSet subset,
                      boolean complement,
                      boolean absolute)
        Do a Gauss-Seidel-style matrix-vector multiplication followed by min/max. i.e. for all s: vect[s] = min/max_{k1,k2} { (sum_{j!=s} P_{k1,k2}(s,j)*vect[j]) / P_{k1,k2}(s,s) } and store new values directly in vect as computed. The maximum (absolute/relative) difference between old/new elements of vect is also returned.
        Parameters:
        vect - Vector to multiply by (and store the result in)
        min1 - Min or max for player 1 (true=min, false=max)
        min2 - Min or max for player 2 (true=min, false=max)
        subset - Only do multiplication for these rows (ignored if null)
        complement - If true, subset is taken to be its complement (ignored if subset is null)
        absolute - If true, compute absolute, rather than relative, difference
        Returns:
        The maximum difference between old/new elements of vect

      • mvMultJacMinMaxSingle

        double mvMultJacMinMaxSingle(int s,
                             double[] vect,
                             boolean min1,
                             boolean min2)
        Do a single row of Jacobi-style matrix-vector multiplication followed by min/max. i.e. return min/max_{k1,k2} { (sum_{j!=s} P_{k1,k2}(s,j)*vect[j]) / P_{k1,k2}(s,s) }
        Parameters:
        s - Row index
        vect - Vector to multiply by
        min1 - Min or max for player 1 (true=min, false=max)
        min2 - Min or max for player 2 (true=min, false=max)

      • mvMultRewMinMax

        void mvMultRewMinMax(double[] vect,
                     STPGRewards rewards,
                     boolean min1,
                     boolean min2,
                     double[] result,
                     java.util.BitSet subset,
                     boolean complement,
                     int[] adv)
        Do a matrix-vector multiplication and sum of action reward followed by min/max, i.e. one step of value iteration. i.e. for all s: result[s] = min/max_{k1,k2} { rew(s) + sum_j P_{k1,k2}(s,j)*vect[j] }
        Parameters:
        vect - Vector to multiply by
        min1 - Min or max for player 1 (true=min, false=max)
        min2 - Min or max for player 2 (true=min, false=max)
        result - Vector to store result in
        subset - Only do multiplication for these rows (ignored if null)
        complement - If true, subset is taken to be its complement (ignored if subset is null)
        adv - Storage for adversary choice indices (ignored if null)

      • mvMultRewMinMaxSingle

        double mvMultRewMinMaxSingle(int s,
                             double[] vect,
                             STPGRewards rewards,
                             boolean min1,
                             boolean min2,
                             int[] adv)
        Do a single row of matrix-vector multiplication and sum of action reward followed by min/max. i.e. return min/max_{k1,k2} { rew(s) + sum_j P_{k1,k2}(s,j)*vect[j] }
        Parameters:
        s - Row index
        vect - Vector to multiply by
        min1 - Min or max for player 1 (true=min, false=max)
        min2 - Min or max for player 2 (true=min, false=max)
        adv - Storage for adversary choice indices (ignored if null)
